HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_PEOPLE_PERC_1: This test indicates that you have Mild anxiety. About 22% of respondents who took this test fall in the same bracket. We recommend reading ahead to understand how you can maintain these levels more efficiently.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_PEOPLE_PERC_2: This test indicates that you have Moderate anxiety. About 54% of respondents who took this test fall in the same bracket. We recommend reading ahead to understand how you can maintain these levels more efficiently.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_PEOPLE_PERC_3: This test indicates that you have Moderate anxiety. About 24% of respondents who took this test fall in the same bracket. We recommend reading ahead to understand how you can maintain these levels more efficiently.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WORRIES_1: Your report suggests that your resilience and the ability to handle ups and downs of life is above baseline. One can infer that your coping mechansims are helping you regulate anxiety well.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WORRIES_2: Your report suggests that you might be experiencing moderate to high levels of anxiety. The frequency of its occurance can affect different areas of your circle including work, relationships and the overall quality of life.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WORRIES_3: It is possible that you are feeling exhausted, tired and burnt out. You need to evaluate coping strategies and form new ones that will be healthier and more sustainable.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WORRIES_4: Our mind works ahead of us to protect us. So sometimes we fear what's going to happen in the future and we feel anxious.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WORRIES_5: While anxiety is your protective response, it is important to learn how to regulate it. Be assured that you can learn tools that help you manage this.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WANTS_1: You have a wonderful set of coping mechanisms that are working well for you. Mental strength comes from regularly practising these coping mechanisms and strategies. Ensure that you take breaks from work and invest time in creative pursuits
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WANTS_2: You display an immense capacity to manage some of the big stressors. In your current state of mind, you could experience mood swings, also possible reactionary responses that may not be planned or intentioned.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WANTS_3: Our brain also has the tendency to treat real and perceived stress with the same intensity. Think of what stress is not relevant for the moment you need to focus on how can you relive some of this stress and plan taking a break.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_THINGS_1: Easygoing-/-Adaptable in the face of stress-/-Calm & Stable-/-Muscle tension and pain-/-Sleep disturbances-/-Apetite disturbances
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_THINGS_2: A mix of cautious with adventure-/-A blend of outgoingness and occasional introversion-/-Migraines-/-Minor viral infections-/-Stress eating
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_THINGS_3: Heightened defense system-/-Sense of overwhelm-/-Possible agitation-/-Digestive problems-/-Backache and muscle tension-/-Mood disturbances
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_RELATIONS_1: Start conversations with clear agenda: What is the end goal?-/-Identify your buttons: Make this a part of partner discussion to identify your triggers, when anxious, these are the buttons that get triggered easily-/-Beware of spillage: Stress can spill from one area of life to another, always keep those around you informed about your current stressors-/-Anxiety motivation: Try to look at what is the anxiety communicating and try to fulfill that need-/-Group wellbeing: Maintain balanced temperament by regularly focusing on overall and holistic wellbeing
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_RELATIONS_2: Practice square breathing before a big communication-/-Ask HALT: Are you hungry, angry, lonely or tired?-/-Begin highly emotional statements with: I feel-/-Take water breaks during confrontational discussions-/-Give a heads up when you are stressed, tired or emotional-/-When sharing, first decide if you want ‚ÄòComfort or Solution?‚Äô
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_RELATIONS_3: Safe words: Curate multiple avenues to reach out and ask for help-/-Active distraction: Get started on a group project such as jigsaw puzzle, crossword etc. to take a break from thoughts-/-Bring your support system into therapy with you to learn techniques that help you-/-Practice grounding and calming with those around you: Breathe together, stretch together or run together-/-Clarify boundaries: Allow others to wait till you are ready to speak about it
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_ACCOMODATION_1: Say No to Triangling: Have as much communication directly with the person as possible, going via a third person builds for multiple perceptions-/-Take timely breaks: Discuss with HR to plan your holidays and vacations, keep them planned as much as possible-/-Power of Neutral language: Disagreements are more manageable when you begin a statement with, ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what I‚Äôm thinking,‚Äù and end it with, ‚ÄúWhat are you thinking?‚Äù-/-Reminders for team engagement: Request HR to organise and reminders for engagement activities to better know your colleagues
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_ACCOMODATION_2: At a given point, focus on 2 major projects and 3 medium tasks-/-10- 10- 10 rule: Every 10 mins look at something 10 feel away for 10 secs-/-Schedule a mental health break every 1.5- 2 months-/-Plan check in meetings with manager, HR and in house therapists-/-Organise work with schedules, priority planners to reduce frenzy with last minute tasks
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_ACCOMODATION_3: Quiet corners: Speak with your team to find you quieter spots in the office to focus better from-/-DSMs: Participate in DSM and other daily meetings to mark as check points-/-Water cooler talks: Engage with work mates about topics apart from work, this helps developing bonds-/-Reminders and affirmations: Post these around your desk and even around office, there's always someone who'd benefit by reading them-/-Access resources: Speak to HR to get in touch with EAP programs
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WHATS_NEXT_1: Small hack: We're not going to ask you to stop overthinking. But can we scheudle it? Schedule an overthinking hour in your day and when worries come up during the day, remind yourself that you'll sit with that thought in your hour.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WHATS_NEXT_2: Nothing can replace the magic of human conversations and therapy. Bhavya Verma and Anjali Menon on our platform hold expertise in this area incase you‚Äôd like to experience this for yourself.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WHATS_NEXT_3: We‚Äôre in 2024, about time we understand how our mind and body impact each other. Connect your fit app with MindPeers to get solid data on this.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_WHATS_NEXT_4: It is recommended that this test is repeated after 3 weeks.
HOW_ANXIOUS_AM_I_CLOSING_NOTE:
Think of anxiety like a fire alarm. You want it to go off when there's a fire but not when you're baking cookies. Let's work with it and learn how to regulate.

With love,
